Well, it's a little more complicated than that, but the short answer is
yes.  I'll give an explanation and try to keep it brief:
 
In general, I try to stay away from using private variables unless there
is a good reason to.  I don't like to take functionality away from
subclasses or other members of the package that would be useful to them.
When I do make things private, I can usually look at whatever effect it
caused, or there is an accessor to help me see that the method did what
it needed to, or caused the side effect that I would expect, in which
case I often consider the appropriate method to be tested.
 
If it is really necessary to make something private as opposed to
protected or package protected, and there is no way to see what effect
it has that is not also private, then I (or whoever wrote the code I am
working with) have hopefully done so because there is an important
reason why all that is private.  If that is the case, the last thing I
want to do to is throw in a more public accessor.  Even if the intent is
just to use it for testing, the fact is it is available for other
classes that might use it.  If the point is to keep other classes from
accessing something, then adding an accessor with a comment saying
"don't use this method, it's only for testing" is dangerous.  If, on the
other hand, there is no reason why other classes should be restricted
from accessing something, then the decision to have it private needs to
be examined.
 
I view it more as adding a few extra lines of code to my tests than
"jumping through hoops," but yes I would rather spend the extra time on
my tests in order to keep my production code clean.
 
Matt

	Metlis, Matthew B. wrote:
	> 
	> I am one of those people who are nervous about creating an
effect just
	> for testing.  To test methods that only modify private fields
like you
	> describe, you can use reflection (which I would personally
prefer).  Use
	> the object's getClass() method then Class's getField() method.
Field
	> extends java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject which has a
	> setAccessible(boolean) method you can use to gain access to a
private
	> field through reflection.  Field has getter methods for its
value.
	> 
	> A security manager can be set up to prevent this bypassing of
the
	> private restriction, but by default you are allowed to do it.
	
	You prefer jumping through all those hoops to just adding a
method? To 
	each his own, but I see that as much more complex than just
adding a 
	method could ever be.
